content: The Act of 1998 is titled the "Haskell Indian Nations University and Southwestern Indian Polytechnic Institute Administrative Systems Act." It includes findings related to the mentioned institutions. The Act of 1998, titled the "Haskell Indian Nations University and Southwestern Indian Polytechnic Institute Administrative Systems Act," acknowledges the importance of culturally sensitive curricula for higher education programs at these institutions. It aims to provide greater autonomy to Haskell Indian Nations University for transitioning to a 4-year university and improving the academic program at the Southwestern Indian Polytechnic Institute. The Act defines key terms such as "Secretary," "employee," "eligible," and "demonstration project." It applies specifically to Haskell Indian Nations University in Lawrence, Kansas. The Act applies to Haskell Indian Nations University in Lawrence, Kansas, and Southwestern Indian Polytechnic Institute in Albuquerque, New Mexico. SEC. 4. AUTHORITY. Each institution named in section 3(b) has the authority to conduct demonstration projects under this Act, without being limited by specific authority under title 5, United States Code. This includes methods for establishing qualification requirements, recruitment, appointment, classification, compensation, assignment, promotion, discipline, and providing incentives to employees. Before starting a demonstration project under this Act, the institution's president must consult with the board of regents and other relevant parties to develop a plan. This plan should outline the project's purposes, the types and number of employees involved, and methods for reducing staff and grade levels. Before starting a demonstration project under this Act, the institution's president must consult with the board of regents and other relevant parties to develop a plan. The plan should include details such as the number of employees, methodology, duration, training, costs, evaluation criteria, and any legal constraints. The plan must be published in the Federal Register, subjected to a public hearing, and notification provided at least 180 days before the project commences. The project must be notified to employees and Congress before commencement. A final plan must be submitted to Congress 90 days prior and employees informed 60 days before. Limitations include no waivers for equal employment opportunity, Indian preference, or veterans' preference laws. The demonstration project cannot waive equal employment opportunity, Indian preference, or veterans' preference laws. It also cannot impose duties related to collective bargaining on classification of positions, pay, benefits, or compensation. Employees cannot be required to pay dues or fees to a labor organization as a condition of employment. Each demonstration project under this Act must start within 2 years of enactment and end within 5 years, with the option to continue for validation purposes. The project can be terminated if it causes hardship or is not in the institution's best interests. The Secretary will conduct an evaluation. The Secretary will evaluate the results of each demonstration project under the Act to improve public management. Institutions named in section 3(b) must cooperate with the Secretary in providing requested information for the evaluation. The Office of Personnel Management will provide information or technical advice upon request for the design, operation, or evaluation of a demonstration project. All applicants, eligibles, and employees of institutions named in section 3(b) are subject to inclusion in a demonstration project under this Act, with certain provisions for benefits. Eligible individuals can choose to remain under current law governing certain benefits before the start of a demonstration project. Employees of institutions named in section 3(b) must have completed at least 1 year of Government service to be eligible for benefits under specific chapters of title 5, United States Code. Employees who have completed at least 1 year of Government service may choose not to participate in a demonstration project that changes benefits under title 5, United States Code. If they opt out, they can continue to receive benefits under the existing subpart G provisions. Additionally, employees who switch to alternative benefit systems during the project can still receive those benefits after the project ends. The demonstration project under the Act allows employees to retain accrued annual and sick leave when becoming subject to the project, in accordance with section 6308 of title 5, United States Code. It ensures that individuals do not lose any rights accrued under the alternative benefits system or the system itself, if continuation is provided for beyond the termination date. The demonstration project allows employees to keep accrued annual and sick leave when joining, as per section 6308 of title 5, United States Code. It ensures individuals retain their rights under the alternative benefits system even if the project continues beyond the end date. The demonstration project allows employees to retain accrued annual and sick leave under section 6308 of title 5, United States Code. Individuals may be entitled to a lump-sum payment based on their remaining leave when joining the project or upon separation. Additionally, individuals with creditable sick leave under section 8339(m) of title 5 may receive retirement credit for their sick leave. Employees participating in the demonstration project can retain accrued annual and sick leave. Sick leave standing to an individual's credit at the time of separation will be creditable, not exceeding the amount at the start of the project. If an employee transfers to another agency without a break in service, their remaining leave will transfer accordingly. Employees participating in the demonstration project can retain accrued annual and sick leave, which will transfer to a new employing agency if they transfer without a break in service. Collective-bargaining agreements will continue to be recognized until the project's completion or after 3 years, whichever comes first. The agreement is scheduled to expire on a specific date determined by mutual agreement of the parties. SEC. 5. DELEGATION OF PROCUREMENT AUTHORITY. The Secretary shall delegate procurement and contracting authority to the presidents of named institutions. SEC. 6. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. Funds are authorized for each institution named in section 3(b) for operations and additional necessary sums. SEC. 7. REGULATIONS. SEC. 7. REGULATIONS. The president of each institution named in section 3(b) may prescribe regulations in consultation with appropriate entities to carry out this Act. SEC. 8. LEGISLATION TO MAKE CHANGES PERMANENT. Institutions conducting demonstration projects must submit recommendations and proposed legislation to Congress before the project expires.
